tossups.question: 1. Walter Kaufmann’s Tragedy and Philosophy calls this play’s protagonist a “passive anti-hero” in contrast with the “noble hero” Oedipus. Skeletal set designs were used in this play by Jo Mielziner for its premiere at the Morosco Theater. A character in this play remarks that it’s bad to “suffer fifty weeks a year for the sake of a two-week vacation” to justify his preference for farming. Its opening describes a “word-sigh” that might be “Oh boy, oh boy” from a man “past sixty years of age,” as well as a (*) “small and fine” melody that re-appears when a character interested in Alaskan properties enters later. This play’s protagonist considers himself “well-liked,” which is a reason he believes he is better than Bernard, and wants to be rich like his brother Ben. For 10 points, name this play about Willy Loman’s demise by Arthur Miller.
tossups.answer: Death of a Salesman <WA, Drama>

tossups.question: 2. This modern-day country is the easternmost one in which significant artifacts from the Corded Ware culture have been found. It’s not Iran, but a ringed stone complex in this country called Arkaim [ar-KAH-eem] has been speculatively linked to the legendary city of Yima, who is called Jamshid in the Shahnameh. The Yamnaya culture was situated in what is now this country, which contains a “forest zone” that is typically given as the Urheimat [OOR-”high”-maht] of the Tocharians [to-CAR-ee-uns]. (*) Steppes in the southern part of this country are the homeland posited by the Kurgan hypothesis. A linguistic affiliation with peoples such as the Mordvins suggests that the Magyars originated in what is now this country, where the word “mammoth” originated from native peoples such as the Chukchi. For 10 points, name this country where the site of Bolghar is found on the Volga river.
tossups.answer: Russia [or Russian Federation; or Rossiyskaya Federatsiya] (the question is referring to the Siberian Forest Zone) <WA, Archaeology>

tossups.question: 3. This noun denotes a party led by a self-labeled “convivial cannibal from the down-coast hinterlands” who created the National Unification policy to better integrate tribesmen, such as the Krahn people. That party denoted by this word sent the first delegation of African heads of state to the White House, including Edwin Barclay. This word names a party that, from the 1870s to 1980s, effectively led a one-party state, but had its dominance broken in a 1960 coup by (*) Samuel Doe. This word denotes a faction whose “Patriot” group opposed a leader backed heavily by Queen Caroline. It names a party that fractured into “Cotton” and “Conscience” factions, the latter of which formed the Free Soil Party. For 10 points, give his word that denotes a faction of anti-monarchists who opposed the Tories and a U.S. party which fractured over slavery.
tossups.answer: Whigs [accept True Whigs or Patriot Whigs] <WA, British/Other History>

tossups.question: 4. A holder of this title invited such literary figures as Plato Comicus and the epic poet Choerilus to his court, and had a man named Decamnichos be whipped for insulting a playwright’s bad breath, prompting Decamnichos to lead a coup against him later. In honor of poems that he wrote for a holder of this title, Pindar’s house in Thebes was spared from a sack in 335 BC. Classical accounts hold that a holder of this title offered patronage to (*) Agathon and Euripides, both of whom moved to his court and died there. This title’s most famous holder was depicted by authors designated “pseudo-Callisthenes” in a series of popular medieval romances, as well as in Arrian’s Anabasis. For 10 points, give this title held by a man tutored by Aristotle called Alexander the Great.
tossups.answer: king of Macedon [accept any answer indicating a ruler of Macedon; prompt on king or Greek king or equivalents] (the first clue refers to Archelaus I, patron of Euripides) <WA, Authors/Bios>

tossups.question: 5. In 1998, teacher Ruth Sherman was fired for reading a book about this feature by Carolivia Herron to her class. The cultural history of this feature is the subject of a book about its “story” by Ayana Byrd and Lori Tharps. In the early 20th century, this feature was frequently manipulated into a “conk.” Commercializing the sales of her homemade treatments for this feature by hiring thousands of female saleswomen enabled the success of an apprentice and rival of Annie Malone; that woman was the first (*) self-made female millionaire in the U.S, Madame C. J. Walker. A way of manipulating this personal feature named for Jheri Redding was popular due to using fewer chemical relaxers. For 10 points, name this bodily feature of African-Americans that has often historically been politicized, and which may be displayed in cornrows or dreadlocks.
tossups.answer: hair [accept black hair or curly hair or Hair Story or Nappy Hair; accept specific hairstyles such as afros or cornrows or dreadlocks, though not all the clues necessarily apply to these] <WA, US History>

tossups.question: 6. After he learns to swim, a boy who grows up in this city becomes fascinated by a sunken minesweeper and later goes diving to retrieve its treasure. A novel whose first part is set in this city parodies Martin Heidegger’s philosophical terminology through nonsense discourse invented by an air force cadet. To get one of his possessions repaired, a character in this city gets his mother’s lover to take him to a post office to visit the janitor Koybella. A character who grows up in this city gathers the (*) uniforms of officers to put on his scarecrows. An Alsatian shepherd befriends a boy who grows up in this city named Walter Matern. After deciding that he would “never under any circumstances be a grocer” at age three, a character in this city decides to stop growing up. For 10 points, name this formerly German city, the setting of a trilogy of novels by Günter Grass.
tossups.answer: Danzig [or Gdansk] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: 7. This non-monarch is generally credited with authoring the initial drafts of a comprehensive slavery policy called the Black Code, though he died two years before it was enacted. This man designed policies to create a “compact colony” after forcing the Company of One Hundred Associates to surrender its charter. This man sent an invitation to Christiaan Huygens to help staff an academy he created, the (*) Royal Academy of Sciences. He had the charters of three existing Asia-based companies fused to create one that operated out of Pondicherry. After bringing in Flemish wool manufacturers and Italian glassmakers to help set up domestic factories, this man forbade the import of Venetian glass in 1672. For 10 points, name this mercantilist finance minister of Louis XIV.
tossups.answer: Jean-Baptiste Colbert <WA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 8. This essay reproduces a parodic passage saying “Louis XIV was a very proud and self-confident man,” contrasting it with the same thinker’s Bergson-like articulation of a calculus that would integrate “differential” human actions. This essay considers a philosopher’s remark that a losing general may play a Te Deum and declare victory as a parallel to how one author uses the battlefield to illustrate “the great illusion” that individuals can “understand and control events.” This essay notes how events recorded in the letters of Joseph de Maistre are reflected in actions of characters like (*) Prince Vasily and Bolkonsky. It considers Pushkin and Dostoevsky as examples of writers who see “many things” and “one big thing,” respectively, and argues that Leo Tolstoy belongs to neither group. A distinction by Archilochus between two animals titles, for 10 points, what Isaiah Berlin essay?
tossups.answer: “The Hedgehog and the Fox” <WA, Phil/SS>

tossups.question: 9. While listening to a man read this work, a character notes that it had been “given back” to him “in the last stage of a desperate adventure, on a Western island.” In a chapter of this work, the bleakness of a rocky landscape causes soldiers to conclude that life lacks value, allowing them to win a battle. The family of this work’s author “curse the name” of the monk who published it, as it is a “shapeless mass of contradictory rough drafts.” A scholar concludes that the word (*) “time” never occurs in this work before a man visiting him asserts “But I am your friend” and shoots him in the back. A story about a man named Fang is used to explain the theme of this work, whose apparently contradictory chapters are elucidated to be a temporal labyrinth by the Sinologist Stephen Albert. For 10 points, identify this incomplete novel by Ts’ui Pen which titles a Jorge Luis Borges story.
tossups.answer: the garden of forking paths [or el jardin de senderos que se bifurcan; accept answers indicating Ts’ui Pen’s novel / book / etc. until “Tsu’i Pen” is read] <WA, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: A priest who opposed this leader’s regime created an artists’ colony on the Solentiname Islands. This man dictated his memoirs to Jack Cox, and titled them after his nation “betrayed.” This man assumed emergency powers in his nation after an earthquake rocked his capital. Riots against this man’s regime broke out after the founder of the UDEL and editor of the newspaper La Prensa was murdered. This leader was targeted by Operation Reptile while living in exile in Paraguay, during which a group of (*) Argentine Marxist revolutionaries killed him with an RPG. This man was overthrown by the FSLN, which subsequently set up the Junta of National Reconstruction. After this man’s overthrow, fighting between the CIA-backed Contras and the Sandinistas broke out in his nation. For 10 points, name this dictator of Nicaragua who was in power until 1979.
tossups.answer: Anastasio Somoza (Debayle) <EM, World History>

tossups.question: 11. In a novel, a chance to play on “I Love Lucy” with Desi Arnaz is awarded to two boys who grow up in this place named Cesar and Nestor. A coming-of-age novel styled as a “biomythography” that depicts the author’s childhood in this place is titled Zami: A New Spelling of My Name. In a third novel set in this place, Dorcas has an affair with the cosmetics salesman Joe Trace. The mixed Danish ancestry of an author who worked in this place reflects the mixed ancestry of Helga Crane in her novel (*) Quicksand. Oscar Hijuelos’ The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love is set in the eastern, “Spanish” part of this place. Jazz by Toni Morrison is set in this place during the 1920s. For 10 points, name this neighborhood home to Nella Larsen, Claude McKay, and Langston Hughes during its namesake “Renaissance.”
tossups.answer: Harlem [accept Home to Harlem; prompt on New York or USA or Manhattan] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: 12. This process titles a book that asserts a “Magian” culture to be the genesis of the Abrahamic and Zoroastrian faiths, as opposed to the “Apollonian” culture of Greece, and claims to be a “Copernican revolution” for the conception of history as “ancient-medieval-modern.” It’s not “history,” but this is the first title process of a book that is often quoted as equating history with the “crimes, follies, and misfortunes of mankind.” Autumn is equated with periods of city-building in a 1918 book titled for this process by (*) Oswald Spengler, one of the two historiography books alluded to by the title of a novel about Paul Pennyfeather. It’s the first title process of a 1776 book that blames Commodus for accelerating a loss of civic virtue and controversially associates its central phenomenon on Christianity. For 10 points, name this process often paired with “fall,” as in the title of an Edward Gibbon book.
tossups.answer: decline [or declinism or downfall or untergang; accept decline and fall; accept The Decline of the West or The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire] <WA, Historiography>

tossups.question: 13. The founder of this party edited the National Observer as a mouthpiece for his ideas and lost an election for governor with John Crary as his running mate. This party was revived by the founder of Wheaton College, Jonathan Blanchard. This party carried Vermont in an election in which Amos Ellmaker was its vice-presidential candidate and was formed after William Morgan was believed to be killed by drowning in the (*) Niagara River. The editor of the Albany Evening Journal, Thurlow Weed, helped found this party. One of its leaders represented the Cherokee nation in Cherokee Nation v. Georgia, served as the prosecutor in Aaron Burr’s treason trial, and served as attorney general under Monroe and Adams. For 10 points, name this party that put William Wirt forward as its candidate in the 1832 election, which was named for its opposition to a secret society.
tossups.answer: Anti-Masonic Party <EM, US History>

tossups.question: 14. Two of this author’s poems were submitted to Poetry magazine under the fake name “Joel Michael Symington” by the poet David Morton. This author’s first poem, inspired by a film adaptation of A Midsummer Night’s Dream, is titled “The Battle” and was written at age 8. This poet drew from the death of his younger brother Richard to pen the lines “Once upon a time there were two brothers / Then there was only one: myself” in his poem “The History of My Life.” In another poem, this poet compares “the (*) principle that makes works of art so unlike / what the artist intended” to a game of telephone. He quotes Vasari in a poem that describes “the right hand / bigger than the head, thrust at the viewer / and swerving easily away” in a Parmigianino painting. For 10 points name this poet of “Self Portrait in a Convex Mirror.”
tossups.answer: John Ashbery <SB, Poetry>

tossups.question: 15. In his book about visiting Sakhalin Island, Anton Chekhov called this playwright a misogynist “who would like to see women enslaved” and labeled him a “spiritual ally” of the island’s native Gilyaks. In a play by this author, a man who is labeled a “charitable scoundrel” leaves his house to receive the blessings of the poor in order to embellish his future obituary. Alice hopes to be murdered during her husband Edgar’s saber dance in a two-part play by this author. The phrase “men are to be pitied” is frequently repeated throughout a play by this author in which (*) Agnes wants to absorb the agonies of the human world before ascending to heaven. In another of his plays, Amalia reveals how Jacob Hummel murdered the milkmaid at a dinner party attended by the student, Arkenholz. For 10 points, name this playwright of A Dream Play and The Ghost Sonata.
tossups.answer: August Strindberg <SB, Drama>

tossups.question: 16. Despite confiscating church lands, a ruler of this polity re-allied with the clergy in order to decrease the power of the Heresy of the Judaizers. The name “Gathering of the Lands” is given to a process of unification accomplished by this polity through such victories as the Battle of Shelon. One of its leaders fended off two sieges by Algirdas, who attacked in support of this polity’s main local rival, Tver. A ruler of this polity attempted to legitimize it as a “Third Rome” by marrying (*) Sophie Palaeologus, and also made a “Great Stand” on the Ugra River. Despite being opposed by an alliance of Mamai, Jogaila, and Oleg II, this polity achieved a great victory at Kulikovo, thus taking the first step at removing the “Tatar yoke.” For 10 points, name this Grand Duchy centered on a namesake city whose final ruler, Ivan the Terrible, crowned himself “Tsar of all the Russias.”
tossups.answer: Grand Duchy of Moscow [or Grand Principality of Moscow; or Muscovy; prompt on Russia or Russian empire or Tsarist Russia] <EM, Continental History>

tossups.question: 17. This person’s actions are compared to Jesus’ prophecy that Peter will deny him three times in E. R. Dodds’ essay on “misunderstanding” a work titled for this person. In a novel, certain politicians are compared to this person because they are not criminals, but rather “convinced they had discovered the only road to paradise.” Ola Rotimi adapted the tale of this person into The Gods are Not to Blame. A (*) surgeon loses his reputation after comparing Communists to this person, because they do not foresee consequences of their actions, in The Unbearable Lightness of Being. Carl Jung introduced a female analogue of a concept named for this man, and named it for Electra. Young men desire to kill their father and marry their mother in the “complex” named after, for 10 points, what Greek tragedic hero?
tossups.answer: Oedipus [accept Oedipus complex; accept “On Misunderstanding the Oedipus Rex”] <WA, Literary Legacy>

tossups.question: 18. Early cultural shifts in the westernmost parts of this river’s basin may be indicated by the appearance of a culture defined by red ochre pottery in 3rd millenium BC, which was succeeded by the Copper Hoard culture. A coin called caltis is said to come from the port of the same name at this river’s mouth, which is the furthest port named in the Periplus of the Erythraean Sea. An imperial capital along this river shaped like a parallelogram was connected by a great road to the far western frontier of Taxila. The iron-rich (*) Magadha kingdom along this river’s banks gave birth to a dynasty ruled by Nanda. An imperial capital along this river was described as surrounded by a 600 foot ditch by Megasthenes. A city along this river, Pataliputra, was the capital of the Gupta Empire. For 10 points, name this river along which the city of Varanasi and the heartland of North Indian civilization lies.
tossups.answer: Ganges River [or Ganga River] <WA, Ancient History>

tossups.question: 19. This character asks his love interest to meet him on Thursdays and Sundays, or whenever she is sent to fetch water, so that he can carry the buckets for her. Despite discovering his family tree in an old Bible, this character declines to recover a silver cup from a boy who stole it. This character masters riding the beautiful, but timid, horse Goblin in order to carry out his new job delivering The Observer. He is given a cracked crucible by (*) Dove, causing him to burn his hand while making a silver teapot for John Hancock. This character, who is apprenticed to the smith Ephraim Lapham, takes up the musket of his role model Rab while fighting alongside Josiah Warren. For 10 points, name this protagonist of a young adult novel by Esther Forbes set during the American Revolution.
tossups.answer: Johnny Tremain [accept either underlined portion] <WA, HistInLit>

tossups.question: 20. This character gifts a special stove to one girl because she is excluded from the rough games of the other boys at her school. In a novel, this character institutes a rule permitting pillow fights every Saturday night in exchange for the residents’ proper bedtimes every other night. She dresses as Mrs. Malaprop for a New Year’s Eve party and learns German from her future husband while staying at a boarding house in New York. This character owns the pet rat Scrabble and nearly lets her sister (*) drown at an ice skating rink as revenge for burning her manuscript. This character inherits the Plumfield Estate from her aunt and turns it into a school for boys. In the first novel she appears in, this character rejects Laurie’s advances and marries Professor Bhaer instead. For 10 points, name this character from Little Women, the second oldest March sister.
tossups.answer: Josephine March [prompt on March] <SB, LongFic>

tossups.question: 21. This book notes that women are allowed to take a new husband by custom if their husband is absent for more than twenty days in a province called Pein. The protagonists of this book visit a southern land called “Mangi” [MAHN-gee] while travelling with the protection of a golden pass historically known as a paiza. Though this book’s narrator remarked “I did not tell half of what I saw, for it would not be believed” on his deathbed, a common name of this book in the narrator’s native tongue supposedly refers to the number of (*) lies it tells. The adventure recounted in this book, which was undertaken by the narrator at age 17 with his uncle Maffeo and father Niccolò, inspired the series of imaginary conversations in Italo Calvino’s novel Invisible Cities. For 10 points, name this book recounting the travels to Khubilai Khan’s court and other exotic locales by Marco Polo.
tossups.answer: Il Milione [or The Million or or Book of the Marvels of the World or The Travels of Marco Polo or Description of the World or Livre des Merveilles du Monde] <WA, Historical Sources>

tossups.question: 22. It’s not a human activity, but a poem titled for this phenomenon fatalistically observes how “Riches or poverty, long or short life” are decided by the “Maker of Things” before describing how the speaker can “lose Heaven and Earth.” In that poem, the speaker describes two companions named “Saint” and “Sage” before noting “Nature and I are one.” In autumn, this phenomenon is seen “through glaze” according to the poem (*) “Marble Stairs Grievance.” The speaker celebrates “under the flowering trees” with a “cup of wine” in a Chinese poem titled for this natural phenomenon, which illuminates the character Pierrot in some Albert Giraud [all-BARE zhee-ROH] poems set to music by Arnold Schoenberg. For 10 points, a poem by Li Bai describes him “Drinking Alone By” what natural phenomenon?
tossups.answer: moonlight [or The Moon; or Luna; or many words that start with Yue; accept Pierrot Lunaire; prompt on light or illumination or other more general answers] <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: 23. A Lenin quote made in the aftermath of the Kronstadt Soviet says “Here or there with” one of these objects, “but not with opposition.” Activist Cesar Lopez presented a guitar inspired by the shape of these objects, the escopetarra, to the current Dalai Lama, who used the word “reasonable” in a statement about them in Portland, Oregon. At the 1938 Sixth Plenary Congress, a leader stated that “Every Communist must grasp the truth” before making a famous statement about these objects. The (*) Mosin-Nagant is an example of these objects, which are crossed with a hoe in a design based on a banner used by FRELIMO. An aphorism by Mao Zedong states that “political power grows out of” part of one of these objects. For 10 points, name these objects that famously feature on Mozambique’s flag, an example of which was designed by Mikhail Kalashnikov.
tossups.answer: guns [accept specific types such as rifles or assault rifles or AK-47s; accept the barrel of a gun] <WA, World History>

tossups.question: 24. This essay calls the Christian Science Monitor “a paper more enlightened than most,” referencing an article by its education editor about how children speak different languages at school than at home. This essay quotes a passage from the autobiography “A Personal Record,” and lambasts the conclusions from a case study by the psychologist Bernard C. Meyer. It opens the collection Hopes and Impediments and was first delivered as a lecture at the University of Massachusetts. This essay refers to Marco Polo’s omission of accounts about the Great Wall to exemplify how even (*) non-xenophobic travelers can be “astonishingly blind,” labels the Thames the “very antithesis” of a certain river, and calls attention to one author’s “best assaults” by quoting the line “Mr. Kurtz — he dead.” For 10 points, name this essay that attacks the racism in Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness, written by Chinua Achebe.
tossups.answer: “An Image of Africa” <SB, Essays/Crit>
